THAT EMPTY SEAT
1. A Flagship-like any ve-

Maybe, on the flight in ques-

devoted to war cargo tharthere

2. Gasoline uses un part of the allowable load
American's flants are so scheduled that the neces-
sary amount of fuel (quantity to be used in flight,
plus a large reserve will normally not limit the
passengers to fewer than 21. However, if winds are
less favoring than is normal, the necessary amount
of fuel is greater, and the flight may be restricted
to fewer passengers.
3. Maybe somebody was a "No Show." A No
Show is one who reserves a seat, then neither uses
it nor recases it for someone else by cancelling the
snace as soon as possible

BECAUSE MORE PLANES ARE IN THE SKY
MORE EXPRESS SPACE IS AVAILABLE
Yes, the flying machines are flying back. America
has achieved fantastic goals of plane production
so the government has been releasing additional
equipment to the airlines. This means that Air Ex-
press has been able to hind more room for shipments
that didn't because of war-time space restrictions.
More planes mean more flights - and that means
more cargo. While much of the equipment released
will do double duty carrying both passengers and
cargo. some of the planes will be used solely to
transport Air Mail and Air Express. And a single one
or these sky giants can carry ooo pounds and over.
Further, larger and more powerful carriers are on
the drawing boards of aviation's designers.
What about war cargo? Priority shipments still
come first; non-priority cargo is handled on a space-
available basis. But more space is available for all
shipments - high, low, and non-priority.
Fact is, Air Express has played an important part
in the war of production kor breakdowns and delaws
come when least expected. New parts are needed
fast when a 24-hr. shift has to wait for an ailing
machine. Delivery dates get snarled up when
one forgets to figure the man-hour shortage. With
Air Express, you can get parts overnight, or sooner
get orders delivered on time - meet, and beat.
the deadliest deadlines. Air Express speed has re-
duced that longer to a very short time indeed
And at those lowered rates indicated below. it's a
must whenever you've something that must 20
places quickly.
RATES REDUCED as Volume Increased
Not all services increased their wartime prices!
As a direct result of the great volume of Air Express
trafic crented by wartime demands and the inc
creased efficiency developed to satisfy these de-
mands Air Exoress rates within the US. were
actually reduced, in some instances as much as
12%, depending on the weight of the shipment and
the distance it moves. Shippers are saving on an
average of 10%% on pre-war Air Express costs.

STILL IMPORTANT.
PACK LIGHTLY -
COMPACTLY - in Small Units
and SHIP WHEN READY!
Don't pay for supertiuous wrappings and trappings
but pack securely. Air Express people are trained
to handle with care and to load scienchcally so vou
don't have to overwrap your shipments.
Smaller packages often can make earlier planes
than bulky ones because they're easier to stow in
odd corners and this helps to provide extra space.
Break your shipments into small units when possible
- expedite vour own delivenes, save time and space
for others, help cut your shipping costs.
And Ship When Ready - as early in the day as
possible. Night flights are more apt to be over-
loaded. You assure yourself of faster delivery by
shipping as soon as ready.
